/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls/1.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,77 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+  SCRIPT=$(basename "${0}")
+ VERSION='2017-04-15'
+  AUTHOR='ffmprovisr'
+     RED='\033[1;31m'
+    BLUE='\033[1;34m'
+      NC='\033[0m'
+
+if [[ ${OSTYPE} = "cygwin" ]] || [ ! $(which diff) ]; then
+    echo -e "${RED}Error: 'diff' is not installed by default. Please install 'diffutils' from Cygwin.${NC}"
+    exit 1
+fi
+
+_output_prompt(){
+    cat <<EOF
+Usage: ${SCRIPT} [-h] | [ -i <av_file> -m <md5_file> ]
+EOF
+    exit 1
+}
+
+_output_help(){
+    cat <<EOF
+Syntax:
+  ${SCRIPT}
+    Prompts a short help message.
+  ${SCRIPT} -h
+    This help.
+  ${SCRIPT} -i <av_file> -m <md5_file>
+    Pass to the script the audio-visual file and the corresponding MD5
+    file to check.
+Dependency:
+  ffmpeg
+About:
+  Version: ${VERSION}
+  Website: https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/blob/gh-pages/check_framemd5.sh
+EOF
+    exit 0
+}
+
+unset input_file
+unset input_hash
+
+while getopts ":hi:m:" opt; do
+    case "${opt}" in
+        h) _output_help ;;
+        i) input_file=$OPTARG ;;
+        m) input_hash=$OPTARG ;;
+        :) echo -e "${RED}Error: option -${OPTARG} requires an argument${NC}" ; _output_prompt ;;
+        *) echo -e "${RED}Error: bad option -${OPTARG}${NC}" ; _output_prompt ;;
+    esac
+done
+
+[[ -z "${#}" || ! ${input_file} || ! ${input_hash} ]] && _output_prompt
+echo -e "${BLUE}Please wait...${NC}"
+unset md5_tmp
+if [[ $OSTYPE = "cygwin" ]]; then
+    md5_tmp=""${USERPROFILE}/$(basename ${input_hash}).tmp""
+else
+    md5_tmp="${HOME}/$(basename ${input_hash}).tmp"
+fi
+# Find audio frame size for hash calculation
+sample_rate=$(grep -v '^#' ${input_hash} | head -n 1 | tr -d ' ' | cut -d',' -f4)

On Mon, Oct 31, 2016 at 3:38 PM, kieranjol notifications@github.com wrote: > ## _@kieranjol_ commented on this pull request. > > In index.html > https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pull/106#pullrequestreview-6509651 > : > > > - > > -
> > -
> > -
> > -
> > -

Generate two access MP3s from input. One with appended audio (such as copyright notice) and one unmodified.

> > -

ffmpeg -i input_file.wav -i input_file_to_append -filter_complex "[0:a:0]asplit=2[a][b];[b]afifo[bb];[1:a:0][bb]concat=n=2:v=0:a=1[concatout]" -map "[a]" -codec:a libmp3lame -dither_method modified_e_weighted -qscale:a 2 output_file.mp3 -map "[concatout]" -codec:a libmp3lame -dither_method modified_e_weighted -qscale:a 2 output_file_appended.mp3

> > -

This script allows you to generate two derivative audio files from a master while appending audio from a seperate file (for example a copyright or institutional notice) to one of them.

> > -
> > -
ffmpeg
starts the command
> > -
-i input file
path, name and extension of the input file (The master file)
> > -
-i input file to append
path, name and extension of the input file (The file to be appended to access file)
> > -
-filter_complex
enables the complex filtering to manage splitting the input to two audio streams
> > -
[0:a:0]asplit=2[a][b];
asplit allows audio streams to be split up for seperate manipulation. This command splits the audio from the first input (the master file) into two streams "a" and "b"
> > -
[b]afifo[bb];
this buffers the stream "b" to help prevent dropped samples and renames stream to "bb"
> > -
[1:a:0][bb]concat=n=2:v=0:a=1[concatout]
concat is used to join files. n=2 tells the filter there are two inputs. v=0:a=1 Tells the filter there are 0 video inputs and 2 audio inputs. This command appends the audio from the second input to the beginning of stream "bb" and names the output "concatout"
> > I'm more familiar with the concat demuxer (textfiles) than the filter, but > when you say v=0:a=1 Tells the filter there are 0 video > inputs and 2 audio inputs. is that correct? I see a=1, does that > definitely mean that there are two audio inputs? > > — > You are receiving this because you authored the thread. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub > https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pull/106#pullrequestreview-6509651, > or mute the thread > https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AMV5g2dq308-X1Sqz4aw4M4b2L9Y6XWFks5q5kOegaJpZM4KlYwu > . ## Andrew Weaver, MLIS American Archive of Public Broadcasting National Digital Stewardship Resident @ CUNY TV weevz@uw.edu

@@ -671,17 +671,28 @@
-

Create Bash Script named “Rewrap-MXF.sh” to do Batch FFmpeg Processing

-

for f in *.MXF; do ffmpeg -i "$f" -map 0 -c copy "${f%.MXF}.mov"; done

-

Re-wrap .MFX files in a specified directory to .mov files by using this code within a .sh file. The shell script (.sh file) and all MXF files must be contained in the same directory, and the script must be run from the directory itself (cd ~/Desktop/MXF_file_directory). Execute .sh file with the command sh Rewrap-MXF.sh

+

Create Bash script to batch process with ffmpeg

+

Bash scripts are plain texts files saved with a .sh extension. This entry explains how they work with the example of a bash script named “Rewrap-MXF.sh”, which rewraps .MXF files in a given directory to .MOV files.

+

“Rewrap-MXF.sh” contains the following text:

+

for file in *.MXF; do ffmpeg -i "$file" -map 0 -c copy "${file%.MXF}.mov"; done

-
-map 0
select all input streams to map to output
-
-c copy
enable stream copy. This will re-mux wihout re-encoding, so quality is preserved
+
for file in *.MXF
starts the loop, and states what the input files will be. Here, the ffmpeg command within the loop will be applied to all files with an extension of .MXF.
+ The word ‘file’ is an arbitrary variable which will represent each .MXF file in turn as it is looped over.
+ Per Bash syntax, within the command this variable is referenced with a dollar sign, e.g. as $file

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/issues/.body:
Yes, this seems like a good start. Using awk is a nice shortcut to show how this could work but I think a fuller solution does call for a script that does some analysis of the YDIF values throughout and sets a cut-off value that fits the individual video. For some cases you'll also want to do some grouping as some scene changes aren't just quick cuts.

@dericed I also wonder if there's any other analysis that ffprobe might be able to do on the frames? So for my purposes a scene cut will often be a frame or second of black, so it would be nice to be able to filter these out. But again that could be a post-processing job after ffprobe does the general analysis of change.

I remember trying the command mentioned by @richardpl in this thread, probably combined with a second pass of `ffmpeg -i <inputvideo> -vf select='gt(scene\,0.7)' -vsync 0 -an keyframes%03d.jpg` and it did a really god job of grabbing scene changes from a feature. 
https://ffmpeg.org/pipermail/ffmpeg-user/2016-April/031962.html
This in now open since approximately one year... cc @dericed @ablwr @jronallo @kieranjol
You could use metadata filter instead of awk to pass pts when signalstats metadata numbers change.

Normalize/Equalize Audio

Calculate Loudness Levels

ffmpeg -i input_file -af loudnorm=print_format=json -f null -

+

This filter calculates and outputs loudness information in json about an input file (labeled input) as well as what the levels would be if loudnorm were applied in its one pass mode (labeled output). The values generated can be used as inputs for a 'second pass' of the loudnorm filter allowing more accurate loudness normalization than if it is used in a single pass.

+

+

Information about PBS loudness standards can be found in the PBS Technical Operating Specifications document. Information about EBU loudness standards can be found in the EBU R 128 recommendation document.

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls/1.diff_hunk:
@@ -1081,6 +1081,111 @@ + +
+

Normalize/Equalize Audio

+ + +
+
+
+
+

Calculate Loudness Levels

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -af loudnorm=print_format=json -f null -

+

This filter calculates and outputs loudness information in json about an input file (labeled input) as well as what the levels would be if loudnorm were applied in its one pass mode (labeled output). The values generated can be used as inputs for a 'second pass' of the loudnorm filter allowing more accurate loudness normalization than if it is used in a single pass.

+

These instructions use the loudnorm defaults, which align well with PBS recommendations for target loudness. More information can be found at the loudnorm documentation.

+

Information about PBS loudness standards can be found in the PBS Technical Operating Specifications document. Information about EBU loudness standards can be found in the EBU R 128 recommendation document.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-af loudnorm
activates the loudnorm filter
+
print_format=json
sets the output format for loudness information to json. This format makes it easy to use in a second pass. For a more human readable output, this can be set to print_format=summary
+
-f null -
sets the file output to null (since we are only interested in the metadata generated)
+
+

+
+
+
+
+ + + + +
+
+
+
+

One Pass Loudness Normalization

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -af loudnorm=dual_mono=true output_file

+

This will normalize the loudness of an input using one pass, which is quicker but less accurate than using two passes. This command uses the loudnorm filter defaults for target loudness. These defaults align well with PBS recommendations, but loudnorm does allow targeting of specific loudness levels. More information can be found at the loudnorm documentation.

+

Information about PBS loudness standards can be found in the PBS Technical Operating Specifications document. Information about EBU loudness standards can be found in the EBU R 128 recommendation document.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-af loudnorm
activates the loudnorm filter with default settings
+
dual_mono=true
(optional) Use this for mono files meant to be played back on stereo systems for correct loudness. Not necessary for multi-track inputs.
+
output_file
path, name and extension for input file
+
+

+
+
+
+
+ + + + +
+
+
+
+

Two Pass Loudness Normalization

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -af loudnorm=dual_mono=true:measured_I=input_i:measured_TP=input_tp:measured_LRA=input_lra:measured_thresh=input_thresh:offset=target_offset:linear=true output_file

+

This command allows using the levels calculated using a first pass of the loudnorm filter to more accurately normalize loudness. This command uses the loudnorm filter defaults for target loudness. These defaults align well with PBS recommendations, but loudnorm does allow targeting of specific loudness levels. More information can be found at the loudnorm documentation.

+

Information about PBS loudness standards can be found in the PBS Technical Operating Specifications document. Information about EBU loudness standards can be found in the EBU R 128 recommendation document.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-af loudnorm
activates the loudnorm filter with default settings
+
dual_mono=true
(optional) use this for mono files meant to be played back on stereo systems for correct loudness. Not necessary for multi-track inputs.
+
measured_I=input_i
use the 'input_i' value (integrated loudness) from the first pass in place of input_i
+
measured_TP=input_tp
use the 'input_tp' value (true peak) from the first pass in place of input_tp
+
measured_LRA=input_lra
use the 'input_lra' value (loudness range) from the first pass in place of input_lra
+
measured_LRA=input_thresh
use the 'input_thresh' value (threshold) from the first pass in place of input_thresh
+
offset=target_offset
use the 'target_offset' value (offset) from the first pass in place of target_offset
+
linear=true
tells loudnorm to use linear normalization
+
output_file
path, name and extension for input file
+
+

+
+
+
+
+ + + + +
+
+
+
+

RIAA Equalization

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -af aemphasis=type=riaa output_file

+

This will apply RIAA equalization to an input file allowing correct listening of audio transferred 'flat' (without EQ) from records that used this EQ curve. For more information about RIAA equalization see the Wikipedia page on the subject.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-af aemphasis=type=riaa
activates the aemphasis filter and sets it to use RIAA equalization
+
output_file
path and name of output file

starts the command
+
input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-af loudnorm
activates the loudnorm filter
+
print_format=json
sets the output format for loudness information to json. This format makes it easy to use in a second pass. For a more human readable output, this can be set to print_format=summary
+
-f null -
sets the file output to null (since we are only interested in the metadata generated)
+
+

+
+
+
+
+ + + + +
+
+
+
+

One Pass Loudness Normalization

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -af loudnorm=dual_mono=true output_file

+

This will normalize the loudness of an input using one pass, which is quicker but less accurate than using two passes. This command uses the loudnorm filter defaults for target loudness. These defaults align well with PBS recommendations, but loudnorm does allow targeting of specific loudness levels. More information can be found at the loudnorm documentation.

+

Information about PBS loudness standards can be found in the PBS Technical Operating Specifications document. Information about EBU loudness standards can be found in the EBU R 128 recommendation document.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-af loudnorm
activates the loudnorm filter with default settings
+
dual_mono=true
(optional) Use this for mono files meant to be played back on stereo systems for correct loudness. Not necessary for multi-track inputs.
+
output_file
path, name and extension for input file
+
+

+
+
+
+
+ + + + +
+
+
+
+

Two Pass Loudness Normalization

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -af loudnorm=dual_mono=true:measured_I=input_i:measured_TP=input_tp:measured_LRA=input_lra:measured_thresh=input_thresh:offset=target_offset:linear=true output_file

+

This command allows using the levels calculated using a first pass of the loudnorm filter to more accurately normalize loudness. This command uses the loudnorm filter defaults for target loudness. These defaults align well with PBS recommendations, but loudnorm does allow targeting of specific loudness levels. More information can be found at the loudnorm documentation.

+

Information about PBS loudness standards can be found in the PBS Technical Operating Specifications document. Information about EBU loudness standards can be found in the EBU R 128 recommendation document.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-af loudnorm
activates the loudnorm filter with default settings
+
dual_mono=true
(optional) use this for mono files meant to be played back on stereo systems for correct loudness. Not necessary for multi-track inputs.
+
measured_I=input_i
use the 'input_i' value (integrated loudness) from the first pass in place of input_i
+
measured_TP=input_tp
use the 'input_tp' value (true peak) from the first pass in place of input_tp
+
measured_LRA=input_lra
use the 'input_lra' value (loudness range) from the first pass in place of input_lra
+
measured_LRA=input_thresh
use the 'input_thresh' value (threshold) from the first pass in place of input_thresh
+
offset=target_offset
use the 'target_offset' value (offset) from the first pass in place of target_offset
+
linear=true
tells loudnorm to use linear normalization
+
output_file
path, name and extension for input file

In other recipes we used mainly -filter:v instead of -vf, therefore I tried to have only one syntax. I added here a remark that’s the same. In fact, for many parameters, there are three different syntaxes… (Perhaps we should add everywhere at the end a short note with the alternative syntaxes?)

I think it's important to have consistent terminology across the recipes. Maybe it's easier to just use one term so that an explanatory note is not required? I wonder if -vf is more commonly used than -filter:v? The ffmpeg filter documentation uses -vf: https://ffmpeg.org/ffmpeg-filters.html
Edit: The main ffmpeg doc says that `-vf` is an alias for `-filter:v`. Perhaps it's more self descriptive to use `filter:v`, and there is more consistency with terms like `filter_complex` than when using `-vf`.
@retokromer and I talked about this before and settled on -filter:v for the reasons you mention (more descriptive, -vf is an alias of).

ffplay some_analogy_vid.mkv -vf crop=iw:20:0:ih-20,scale=iw:ih*20:flags=neighbor,setdar=4/3,drawgrid=width=iw:height=ih/20:t=1:c=yellow

This is the core of the Bash script that is currently in production (and would need a lifting ;-)

``` bash
RED='\033[0;31m'
GREEN='\033[0;32m'
NC='\033[0m'

av_file="$1"
md5_file="$2"
md5_tmp="$2.tmp"
$(ffmpeg -y -i $av_file -loglevel 0 -f framemd5 $md5_tmp)
file=$(cat $md5_file)
tmp=$(cat $md5_tmp)
if [ "$file" = "$tmp" ]; then
    echo -e "${GREEN}No errors were found!${NC}"
else
    echo -e "${RED}ERROR: The following differences were detected:${NC}"
    diff "$md5_file" "$md5_tmp"
fi
rm "$md5_tmp"
```
Wow, including setting color variables!
This would fail if the version of the framemd5 changes but the contents are the same. Instead of cat the md5's should be grepped out via their regex.

It's just what is running at the moment on our servers, not for direct inclusion in ffmprovisr.

Following @dericed's suggestion, I am planning to code it as an FFmpeg patch, as soon as we have closed the 2015 accounts etc. (somewhere in late January or early February, I guess).

``` bash
file=$(grep -v '^#' $md5_file)
tmp=$(grep -v '^#' $md5_tmp)
```

Hi Reto, I never used Cygwin much, but I ran into a few issues:

Firstly, when you drag and drop a file, it shows up as: `/cygdrive/c/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/DLD_024-003_03.mkv`
which is fine until an application is calling a file from a script, in which case you need to change it to `c:/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/DLD_024-003_03.mkv
`

Not too big of a deal, and maybe there's a way around it, but it's a little awkward (on cygwins's part, not your script!) .
Another issue is that you're using diff and this doesn't seem to install by default in a vanilla cygwin install. Perhaps a warning could be included in the script if diff isn't available?

`
kieranjol@kieranjol-PC ~
$ /cygdrive/c/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/check_framemd5.sh c:/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/DLD_024-003_03.mkv c:/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/DLD_024-003_03.framemd5  grep: /home/kieranjol/DLD_024-003_03.framemd5.tmp: No such file or directory
ERROR: The following differences were detected between 'DLD_024-003_03.mkv' and 'DLD_024-003_03.framemd5':
/cygdrive/c/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/check_framemd5.sh: line 69: diff: command not found
rm: cannot remove ‘/home/kieranjol/DLD_024-003_03.framemd5.tmp’: No such file or directory
`

Installing `diffutils` fixes this though.

I think cygwin gets confused by the $home reference in your script when generating the tmp file:

`kieranjol@kieranjol-PC ~
$ /cygdrive/c/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/check_framemd5.sh c:/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/DLD_024-003_03.mkv c:/Users/kieranjol/Downloads/DLD_024-003_03.framemd5
grep: /home/kieranjol/DLD_024-003_03.framemd5.tmp: No such file or directory
ERROR: The following differences were detected between 'DLD_024-003_03.mkv' and 'DLD_024-003_03.framemd5':
diff: /home/kieranjol/DLD_024-003_03.framemd5.tmp: No such file or directory
rm: cannot remove ‘/home/kieranjol/DLD_024-003_03.framemd5.tmp’: No such file or directory
`

On a side note, your framemd5 call doesn't include -an. There probably would be a lot of diff errors if someone only ran a framemd5 on their video and then did a fresh compare which included the audio.
Thank you very much, @kieranjol! I will try to fix it in the next days (before I am leaving for a trip to Southeast Asia).
You're more than welcome, @retokromer . I'll do my best to test out the next version as well.

P.S: I made some alterations and the script works as intended, presuming I change the filenames after dragging and dropping them:

I used $home in order to be sure (on OS X and Linux) that the temp file can be written. If you use the path to a write protected media (e.g. a data DVD or a LTO tape), then you get an error.
Does ~/ work on Windows?

Ah, good idea.. In Cygwin `~/` performs the same function as $HOME, in that it points to home/kieranjol rather than c:/Users/Kieranjol.
In Cygwin, the function you require is actually `$USERPROFILE`

I updated the script to test for `diff` and included `$USERPROFILE` as a test. Perhaps it's possible for the script to test if it's real bash vs Cygwin, and md5tmp could be set to the appropriate variable?

For something different, in the «bilingual» Linux/Mac context, I do:

``` bash
if [[ ${OSTYPE} == "darwin"* ]]; then
    if ! tmp_loc="$(type -p "$(brew --prefix gnu-getopt)/bin/getopt")" || [ -z "$tmp_loc" ]; then
        brew install gnu-getopt
        brew link --force gnu-getopt
    fi
fi
```

+

Create FFv1 Version 3 video in a Matroska container with framemd5 of input

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -map 0 -dn -c:v ffv1 -level 3 -g 1 -slicecrc 1 -slices 16 -c:a copy output_file.mkv -f framemd5 -an md5_output_file

+

This will losslessly trancode your video with the FFv1 Version 3 codec in a Matroska container. In order to verify losslessness, a framemd5 of the source video is also generated. For more information on FFv1 encoding, try the ffmpeg wiki.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command.
+
-i input_file
path, name and extension of the input file.
+
-map 0
Map all streams that are present in the input file. This is important as ffmpeg will map only one stream of each type (video, audio, subtitles) by default to the output video.
+
-dn
ignore data streams (data no). The matroska container does not allow data tracks.

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/issues/.body:
Hello Andrew,

as lossless, do you mean something like the following?
- https://avpres.net/FFmpeg/sq_YUV422_10.html
- https://avpres.net/FFmpeg/sq_YUV422_8.html

Best regards, Reto

Hi Reto,

I think your instructions to transcode an image sequence is very valuable and should also be included.

In terms of using lossless processing, I was more thinking about the great feature in FFMPEG to create files without re-encoding, highlighting the lossless nature, speed and low compute requirements of -c copy. As an example, this might be needed when a full broadcast compile news videotape is digitised, and individual news items can then be made as a unique preservation file.

regards,
Andrew
Thank you, Andrew, for clarifying this to me. Best regards, Reto

CC @kieranjol 
In terminal:
`split -b1m input_file part_`
`cat part_* > output_file`
would make it (in my example 1M parts).
Hi! I'll try to give this a go over the weekend.

I guess this is not an FFmpeg-related issue, but are e.g.
`split -b1m input_file part_`
and
`cat part_* > output_file`
working under Windows? And, if so, should I add this to ffmprovisr?

Hi Reto, similar story to the framemd5 thread. Those tools are not available in the standard windows terminals but work very well in git bash.
I split and reconstructed an ffv1.mkv with matching checksums.
I'm not sure of the benefits of adding this to ffmprovisr as the split parts didn't play back. They did work fine if I transcoded to mpeg2 though. Perhaps the `cat` part could be helpful for certain file types, but i think `-f concat -c copy` is preferable?

I guess `copy \b input_file_1 + input_file_2 + input_file_3 output_file` works in DOS (`\b` for binary mode).

Yet I think this does not fit into ffmprovisr. Thoughts?

Are your reasons for thinking it doesn't fit just based on it not being an ffmpeg command? I'm in favor of the idea of expanding the scope to include non-ffmpeg commands if they are related to the same end goal of supportive scripting a/v preservation. But if the reason is lack of use case, I defer.

Just to flag that there are ffmprovisr forks that may be more suited, such
as the sourcecaster: https://datapraxis.github.io/sourcecaster/ and CRALS:
http://dd388.github.io/crals/

+

This filter allows visual analysis of the information held in various bit depths of an audio stream. /repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/issues/.body:
Hi Katherine,

All looks good to me in terms of the commands (I know very little about the html side of things), but I noticed that your Windows path examples are absolute paths. These have been judged 'unsafe' in recent ffmpeg builds:
info here:
https://ffmpeg.org/pipermail/ffmpeg-user/2016-March/031487.html

and
https://ffmpeg.org/pipermail/ffmpeg-user/2016-March/031489.html

and 
https://www.ffmpeg.org/ffmpeg-formats.html#Options

I ended up encountering this issue recently after updating all my builds, so perhaps information about this should be included in the ffmprovisr recipe, with the solution of using `-safe 0` if a user wants to use an absolute path?

Edit: This hasn't been added to the ffmpeg wiki either, so I should try to add to that when I get a chance.
Good to know! I simply went by the ffmpeg wiki on that. I'll update that.
Not sure exactly when it happened, this commit from March looks like it might be the one: https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/689211d5727231c3fe92762d224dbadebdbf4e30
Really good catch. Thanks, Kieran! I've amended, LMK what you reckon.

LGTM! Thanks for adding that.

On Wed, May 18, 2016 at 1:25 PM, Katherine Frances Nagels <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Really good catch. Thanks, Kieran! I've amended, LMK what you reckon.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pull/63#issuecomment-220010432
Thank you once more, @kfrn and @kieranjol! BTW: The "old" format works only if the "old" naming rules are followed.

Recently needed a testvideo with image _and_ sound.
Therefore added SMPTE-bars + sinewave example.
Excellent! Thank you, @pjotrek-b
My pleasure :smile:
Ah yes. One btn.

I think this is a brilliant addition, I like the extension /container explanation. Can't verify this ATM but ,iirc, do these tests create Rgb video by default? Could be nice to add a video codec and pixel format option so people know they can generate the test files in whatever format they want, similar to what you've written about container, something like `-c:v libx264 -pix_fmt yuv420p`?
:+1: @kieranjol ! I believe you are so right and that's such a good idea.

I did some tests on my website. I think SD and HD bars with `ffplay` could also be useful. (At least I use this to test the settings, before presentations.)
http://avpres.net/FFmpeg/#ch7
I second @kieranjol about adding format.
I'll do my favorite thing -- create an issue and assign myself.
:+1: about your comment on ffplay, @retokromer

Hmm… isn’t it quicker to change
directly the code? ;-)
BTW: I think this weekend I can also add some `ffprobe` stuff we use on both ffmprovisr and website.
;) helps me keep my github streak going ;)
@ablwr @kieranjol I suggest to add the `target="_blank"` parameter to the `<a>` tag for external links. If it's OK with you I will made it.
@retokromer Good idea!

– I added the «missing» `target="_blank"` and `ffplay` SMPTE bars for HD and VGA.
– Examples of `ffprobe` will follow. I’m still trying to find the most interesting ones in an archival context.

I use the following to get starting timecode via ffprobe
`ffprobe -v error -select_streams v:0 -show_entries format_tags=timecode:stream_tags=timecode -of default=noprint_wrappers=1:nokey=1 inputfile`
The reason I have both `format` and `stream` is that some MXFs (some AS-11 test files I have) won't reveal their timecodes if you just look purely at the streams. Not sure how common it is, though. This has generally been reliable for me, as long as timecode exists in some form within a file.
Once I store it as a variable, I can use it in combination with the burnt in timecode command.
I can add this one at some stage unless it seems wonky to ye.
Also, for access work, I generally find frame size, duration, framerate to be useful in conjunction with other scripts.

Thank you, @kieranjol, your contribution is very valuable, as usual!
I am at the moment testing some «silent» variants, that allow to process the output directly (aka very easily) on other programmes, without headers. Trying to figure out what could be the most useful.

You're welcome Reto. 
If I understand your meaning correctly, my timecode example is "silent", in that it only produces the value within the terminal, nothing else is shown. Is that what you meant?  Although when actually using it as part of a larger script, I just assign it as a variable and it never appears in the terminal. I'll await your examples and structure my contributions based on yours, because mine are most likely not best practise.
Sorry, as «silent» I was referring to parameters like `-hide_banner` and `-loglevel 0` for my `ffprobe` parts. Not yours.
Hmm… you said extracting «frame size, duration, framerate» etc.? **That** could be an excellent example of use of a bash script! Let’s try to include ffprobe in a bash loop.

`format=pix_fmts=yuv420p` can be shortened to `format=yuv420p`, and `yadif=1` often looks better than the default mode `0` depending on your content. Note that mode `1` will double the output frame rate which is expected because it will output one frame for each field. Also, there are other deinterlacers available to try such as [bwdif](https://ffmpeg.org/ffmpeg-filters.html#bwdif) and [w3fdif](https://ffmpeg.org/ffmpeg-filters.html#w3fdif).

A few points: I believe that `-to` requires a dash for ffmpeg to incorporate it. I'm not sure if `-to` is preferable to `-t`, but I'd say `-to` is fine : https://ffmpeg.org/ffmpeg.html#Main-options

Also according to this: https://trac.ffmpeg.org/wiki/Seeking#Cuttingsmallsections
It could be preferable to have the first `-ss` as an input option, as it might be faster? I could be wrong on this so advice welcome!

Edit: It looks like `-copyts` should be added in order to use `-ss` as an input option if you want to use the timestamps of your input file.

Hi Kieran, you're quite right - how did I miss that command? I guess I was looking for the word 'trim'. Apologies.
And yes, that's a typo - it should be `-to`, I'll correct that.
I prefer using `-to` rather than `-t`, but in many cases you could use either. 
Regarding `-copyts`, I think that's only necessary if you put `-ss` before the input, which indeed is the faster seek option. So it would either be:
`ffmpeg -i input_file -ss 00:02:00 -to 00:55:00 -c copy output_file`  **or**
`ffmpeg -ss 00:02:00 -i input_file -to 00:55:00 -c copy -copyts output_file`
I went with the simpler option, but I welcome discussion on this!

Personally I prefer «Trim» over «Trim start and end». My taste.

`-t` means a duration in time
`-to` means a specific point in the stream
That is not exactly the same, but often you can use either of it. (There is at least one exception I came across, but I don’t remember the details at the moment.) You **cannot** use both in the same command.

A trim «in the middle» command could be good way to introduce the `-to` parameter. I guess we should replace the existing command by a combination of the two commands, in order to not confuse the newcomers.

Hey! Not sure if this is what you were thinking, but when I was looking into detelecine filters I used qctools to compare/analyze results. I would set it to show me the full image on one side and the field split on the other and then advance frame by frame to see what effect the filter was having. Seems like this approach could work to compare the effects of deinterlace filters!

I did some quick tests in the past, I guess five years ago or so. And this should indeed be analysed again and in-depth!

At that time, the default bilinear was clearly the fastest and yadif having the best ratio between speed and quality. We have used internally a self-made filter for one single project, because the artist was unhappy with all the existing filters. It gave an excellent quality, but it was much slower than yadif. We currently use almost always yadif.

A little similar question also rises about the variants of 4:2:0 subsampling.

Related, I had been thinking about an IVTC filter. Many use AVISynth for IVTC, but I'm experimenting with ffmpeg for this.

ffmpeg
starts the command
-i input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
-
-ss 5
Tells ffmpeg what timecode in the file to look for to start copying, and specifies the number of seconds into the video that ffmpeg should start copying. To be more specific, you can use timecode such as 00:00:05.
-
-t 10
Tells ffmpeg to stop copying from the input file after a certain time, and specifies the number of seconds after which to stop copying. In this case, 10 seconds is specified.
-
-c copy
use stream copy mode to re-mux instead of re-encode
+
-ss 00:02:00
sets in point at 00:02:00
+
-to 00:55:00
sets out point at 00:55:00
+
-c copy
use stream copy mode (no re-encoding)
+
Note: watch out when using -ss with -c copy if the source is encoded with an interframe codec (e.g., H.264). Since ffmpeg must split on i-frames, it will seek to the nearest i-frame to begin the stream copy.
output_file
path, name and extension of the output file
+

Variation: trim video by setting duration, by using -t instead of -to

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -ss 00:05:00 -t 10 -c copy output_file

+
-ss 00:05:00 -t 10
+
Beginning five minutes into the original video, this command will create a 10-second-long excerpt.

I think it's worth revising and noting!!!
I suggest to add also a note for http://amiaopensource.github.io/ffmprovisr/#transcode_h264 about `-qp` vs `-crf`. In my opinion, in an archival context, `-qp` should be preferred.

Made some changes for constant quality on my branch here: https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/commit/5ecc763f6dd9f9cc447d3933c5c75b56c41a46e4#diff-eacf331f0ffc35d4b482f1d15a887d3b. What do peeps think of the wording?
LGTM
Resolved, yes?
Solved in https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pull/111/commits/5ecc763f6dd9f9cc447d3933c5c75b56c41a46e4

I think longer scripts are useful, especially to people that aren't brand-new to using ffmpeg, but am wondering about, like what you said, equal support regardless of user operating system.

Since we moved forward with categories, we could have a category not based on type of use but based on extended use of ffmpeg within scripts.

:+1: 

I was thinking at Nicole’s script. And I will think about the interoperability.

I think my workplace seems to be in the minority in terms if having windows as well as osx workstations.
Perhaps it could be OK to have multiple languages represented,as one could understand the general logic of how to harness FFmpeg in different contexts? I am familiar with bash and python,but would love to see a perl or ruby FFmpeg script as it would allow me to see familiar use cases within an unfamiliar language.
There could also be an option to choose a language for a task,though that would require volunteers to "port" the scripts.
P.S, I would gladly try to find the time to do some of that porting.
I just tested: runs fine on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS and on Slackware 14.1.

I am very familiar with Perl (< 6). A large part of my websites is generated on the fly by Perl and MariaDB! Yet Python or Ruby are more sexy. I do not have a clear idea about Perl 6, just made recently some tests: https://gist.github.com/retokromer/bdea769e90fdc277fc13

```
I guess if you set the `_platform` then it will work.

Yeah,I never set the Linux platform check now that I think of it! I'm
hoping the osx escaping will carry over to Linux though. Will work on that
next week.
Anyhow, I remember having difficulty tracking down examples of FFmpeg
python scripts at the time. Lots of bash out there. I'd love to see some
perl! Just a general suggestion anyhow.

Edit: just saw your perl now. I think that's fascinating! Also, I know now what you mean about Nicole's example. It's a bash script but still a nice one liner.
On 10 Jan 2016 4:32 pm, "Reto Kromer" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I guess if you set the _platform the works.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/issues/39#issuecomment-170365593
> .
I have tried to fix it. But now knowing Python, I didn't succeed. It was better and better, and finally a mess. Now I am going to prepare our dinner. Perhaps I try again after.

I'm back at a computer now. Will give it a go, but any other additions would be more than welcome!
Looks like the _platform value for Ubuntu 14.04 is `linux2` (looks like most linux distros, including Ubuntu are just `linux` - also it looks like it requires different escaping from OSX.

Fixed for PAL in here: https://github.com/kieranjol/pyh264bitc/commit/c15ce53d01e5ac9171b2aa4064da76327566e223
I just put an NTSC file through and dropframe semicolons aren't escaped, so they fail. I generally only think in PAL terms but I try to make everything work if possible. Also I should add a `or _platform = "linux"` as I'm not sure how common `linux2` is as a value. I must also get ready for dinner!

More generally speaking, for adding Bash scripts info ffmprovisr, I guess we should include OS X and Linux users, as well as Windows users having installed `cygwin` or `msys` on their computers. Then, if I understand correctly, it should work. I'll try to find such a testing machine.
Bash should be functional on Windows 10 installations soon. That would make things easy.
Do we feel this is ... resolved?
I think so anyhow. It is possible to run the bash scripts on ffmprovisr in a cross-platform way, so this issue is no longer relevant. Feel free to reopen.

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls/5.diff_hunk:
@@ -755,6 +755,45 @@ + + +
+
+
+
+

Combine audio tracks into one in a video file

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -filter_complex "[0:a:0][0:a:1]amerge[out]" -map 0:v -map "[out]" -c:v copy -shortest output_file

+

This command combines two audio tracks present in a video file + into one stream. It can be useful in situations where a downstream + process, like YouTube's automatic captioning, expect one audio + track. To ensure that you’re mapping the right audio tracks run + ffprobe before writing the script to identify which tracks are + desired. More than two audio streams can be combined by extending the + pattern present in the -filter_complex option.

+
+
ffmpeg
+
starts the command
+
-i input_file
+
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-filter_complex [0:a:0][0:a:1]amerge[out]
+
combines the two audio tracks into one
+
-map 0:v
+
map the video
+
-map "[out]"
+
map the combined audio defined by the filter
+
-c:v copy
+
copy the audio

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls/1.body: Why is this necessary?

To make an optical gap between video and audio-only commands.
First wanted to introduce an "audio" headline, but that looked bloated...

You could mention in a note, that there are many possibilities in `lavfi`, e.g. you can evaluate any mathematical function:
```
ffmpeg -f lavfi -i aevalsrc="sin(440*2*PI*t)" -t 10 la.wav
```

@@ -537,6 +537,36 @@ + + +
+
+
+
+

Cover head switching noise

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -vf drawbox=w=iw:h=7:y=ih-h:t=max output_file

+

This command will draw a black box over a small area of the bottom of the frame, which can be used to cover up head switching noise.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
-i input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-vf drawbox=
+
This calls the drawtext filter with the following options: +
+
w=in_w
Width is set to the input width. Shorthand for this command would be w=iw
+
h=7
Height is set to 7 pixels.
+
y=ih-h
Y represents the offset, and ih-h sets it to the input height minus the height declared in the previous parameter, setting the box at the bottom of the frame.
+
t=max
T represents the thickness of the drawn box. Default is 3.

In order to use the same basic command to make a higher quality file, you can add some of these presets:

ffmpeg -i input_file -c:v libx264 -pix_fmt yuv420p -preset veryslow -crf 18 -c:a copy output_file

-
-preset veryslow
This option tells ffmpeg to use the slowest preset possible for the best compression quality.
-
-crf 18
Specifying a lower CRF will make a larger file with better visual quality. 18 is often considered a “visually lossless” compression.
+
-preset veryslow
This option tells ffmpeg to use the slowest preset possible for the best compression quality.
+ Available presets, from slowest to fastest, are: veryslow, slower, slow, medium, fast, faster, veryfast, superfast, ultrafast.
+
-crf 18
Specifying a lower CRF will make a larger file with better visual quality. The scale ranges between 0-51, with 0 being lossless and 51 the worst possible quality.

@@ -964,6 +964,66 @@ + + +
+
+
+
+

Creates a QCTools report

+

ffprobe -f lavfi -i "movie=input_file:s=v+a[in0][in1],[in0]signalstats=stat=tout+vrep+brng,cropdetect=reset=1:round=1,idet=half_life=1,split[a][b];[a]field=top[a1];[b]field=bottom,split[b1][b2];[a1][b1]psnr[c1];[c1][b2]ssim[out0];[in1]ebur128=metadata=1,astats=metadata=1:reset=1:length=0.4[out1]" -show_frames -show_versions -of xml=x=1:q=1 -noprivate | gzip > input_file.qctools.xml.gz

+

This will create an XML report for use in QCTools for a video file with one video track and one audio track.

+
+
ffprobe
starts the command
+
-f lavfi
tells ffprobe to use the Libavfilter input virtual device [more]
+
-i
input file and parameters
+
"movie=input_file:s=v+a[in0][in1],[in0]signalstats=stat=tout+vrep+brng,cropdetect=reset=1:round=1,idet=half_life=1,split[a][b];[a]field=top[a1];[b]field=bottom,split[b1][b2];[a1][b1]psnr[c1];[c1][b2]ssim[out0];[in1]ebur128=metadata=1,astats=metadata=1:reset=1:length=0.4[out1]"
+
This very large lump of commands declares the input file and passes in a request for all potential data signal information for a file with one video and one audio track
+
-show_frames
asks for information about each frame and subtitle contained in the input multimedia stream
+
-show_versions
asks for information related to program and library versions
+
-of xml=x=1:q=1
sets the data export format to XML
+
-noprivate
hides any private data that might exist in the file
+
| gzip
The | is to "pipe" (or push) the data into a compressed file format
+
>
redirects the standard output (the data made by ffprobe about the video)
+
input_file.qctools.xml.gz
names the zipped data output file, which can be named anything but needs the extension qctools.xml.gz for compatibility issues

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls?s.body:
To partially address https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/issues/150 I made a homebrew formula at https://github.com/amiaopensource/homebrew-amiaos/blob/ffmprovisr/ffmprovisr.rb.

This simple script would provide an easy shortcut to open the local ffmprovisr install via terminal.  Only supports homebrew/macOS but would be easy to add in a path for linuxbrew.

If this is merged/new release made then the brew formula could be updated and merged (currently would error since this script doesn't exist in the most recent release).

* revised to remove apology as per https://github.com/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/issues/182

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls?s.body:
Unfortunately, the link to FFmpeg's video sources filter is a moving target:
The existing video sources are part of the link URI:

https://ffmpeg.org/ffmpeg-filters.html#allrgb_002c-allyuv_002c-color_002c-haldclutsrc_002c-nullsrc_002c-rgbtestsrc_002c-smptebars_002c-smptehdbars_002c-testsrc_002c-testsrc2_002c-yuvtestsrc

Therefore, most links pointing there were outdated, so I've updated and fixed them.

It might actually be a good idea to discuss with FFmpeg devs to change the documentation source so the link stays the same though.

+

Generate two access MP3s from input. One with appended audio (such as copyright notice) and one unmodified.

+

ffmpeg -i input_file.wav -i input_file_to_append -filter_complex "[0:a:0]asplit=2[a][b];[b]afifo[bb];[1:a:0][bb]concat=n=2:v=0:a=1[concatout]" -map "[a]" -codec:a libmp3lame -dither_method modified_e_weighted -qscale:a 2 output_file.mp3 -map "[concatout]" -codec:a libmp3lame -dither_method modified_e_weighted -qscale:a 2 output_file_appended.mp3

+
+

starts the command
+
-i input file
path, name and extension of the input file (The master file)

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls/1.body: underscores missing here too
/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls/1.diff_hunk:
@@ -660,6 +660,37 @@ + + + +
+
+
+
+

Generate two access MP3s from input. One with appended audio (such as copyright notice) and one unmodified.

+

ffmpeg -i input_file.wav -i input_file_to_append -filter_complex "[0:a:0]asplit=2[a][b];[b]afifo[bb];[1:a:0][bb]concat=n=2:v=0:a=1[concatout]" -map "[a]" -codec:a libmp3lame -dither_method modified_e_weighted -qscale:a 2 output_file.mp3 -map "[concatout]" -codec:a libmp3lame -dither_method modified_e_weighted -qscale:a 2 output_file_appended.mp3

+

This script allows you to generate two derivative audio files from a master while appending audio from a seperate file (for example a copyright or institutional notice) to one of them.

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
-i input file
path, name and extension of the input file (The master file)
+
-i input file to append
path, name and extension of the input file (The file to be appended to access file)
+
-filter_complex
enables the complex filtering to manage splitting the input to two audio streams
+
[0:a:0]asplit=2[a][b];
asplit allows audio streams to be split up for seperate manipulation. This command splits the audio from the first input (the master file) into two streams "a" and "b"
+
[b]afifo[bb];
this buffers the stream "b" to help prevent dropped samples and renames stream to "bb"
+
[1:a:0][bb]concat=n=2:v=0:a=1[concatout]
concat is used to join files. n=2 tells the filter there are two inputs. v=0:a=1 Tells the filter there are 0 video inputs and 2 audio inputs. This command appends the audio from the second input to the beginning of stream "bb" and names the output "concatout"
+
-map "[a]"
this maps the unmodified audio stream to the first output
+
-codec:a libmp3lame -dither_method modified_e_weighted -qscale:a 2
sets up mp3 options (using constant quality)
+
output file
path, name and extension of the output file (unmodified)
+
-map "[concatout]"
this maps the modified stream to the second output
+
-codec:a libmp3lame -dither_method modified_e_weighted -qscale:a 2
sets up mp3 options (using constant quality)
+
output file appended
path, name and extension of the output file (with appended notice)

ffmpeg -i input_file -bsf noise=1 -c copy output_file

ffmpeg
starts the command
-
-i input_file.dv
takes in a normal DV file
-
-bsf noise
sets bitstream filters for all to 'noise'. The noise filter intentionally damages the contents of packets without damaging the container
+
-i input_file
takes in a normal file
+
-bsf noise=1
sets bitstream filters for all to 'noise'. Filters can be set on specific filters using syntax such as -bsf:v for video, -bsf:a for audio, etc. The noise filter intentionally damages the contents of packets without damaging the container. This sets the noise level to 1 but it could be left blank or any number above 0.

-c copy on the one hand, and -c:v copy or -c:a copy on the other are **NOT** the same!
Only -c copy use stream copy mode to re-mux instead of re-encode, not the others.

`-c copy` is to copy all mapped streams
`-c:a copy` is to copy all mapped audio streams
`-c:v copy` is to copy all mapped video streams
Apologies, I assumed that the generic explanation for `-c copy` and `-c:a copy` was sufficient. PR closed.
Hello @kieranjol, I think a more consistent explanation is indeed fine! There is a speed difference if it is re-recoded or "only" re-muxed.

Hi Kieran, I should clarify that the `-c copy -aspect` move would only change the aspect ratio of the container if this is possible. If the stream you are copying includes its own aspect ratio, such as DV or FFV1, then the result could be conflicting. For instance if DV is in MOV and both the DV and MOV note an aspect ratio, then `-c copy -aspect` would change the MOV aspect ratio but not the DV aspect ratio (changing the DV aspect ratio could not be done with `-c copy`).

Out of curiosity, is `-vf setsar` the only way to change the aspect ratio at a codec level with ffmpeg? Is it a similar case with `-vf setfield`? As stream copy mode is not applicable when using `-vf`, is there any lossless method of aspect ratio change within ffmpeg?

I know this thread is old, but... :wink: 

I've dealt with this [a long time ago](http://ffmpeg.org/pipermail/ffmpeg-user/2012-April/006201.html), but my understanding is that it'd require codec-specific routines to change SAR/DAR/PAR inside the codec's bitstream without re-encoding.

So far, I think ffmpeg only provides to (a) override it using container's metadata, or (b) re-encode.

Would be great to have institutions fund implementing such bitstream-fix functionality in e.g. MediaConch?
Why not directly in FFmpeg and provide an interface in MediaConch?

You're right.

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls/1.diff_hunk:
@@ -600,6 +600,40 @@ + + +
+
+
+
+

This will play two input videos side by side while also applying the temporal difference filter to them

+

ffmpeg -i input01 -i input02 -filter_complex "[0:v:0]tblend=all_mode=difference128[a];[1:v:0]tblend=all_mode=difference128[b];[a][b]hstack[out]" -map [out] -f nut -c:v rawvideo - | ffplay - +

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
-i input01 -i input02
Designates the files to use for inputs one and two respectively
+
-filter_complex
Lets FFmpeg know we will be using a complex filter (this must be used for multiple inputs)
+
[0:v:0]tblend=all_mode=difference128[a]
Applies the tblend filter (with the settings all_mode and difference128) to the first video stream from the first input and assigns the result to the output [a]
+
[1:v:0]tblend=all_mode=difference128[a]
Applies the tblend filter (with the settings all_mode and difference128) to the first video stream from the second input and assigns the result to the output [b]
+
[a][b]hstack[out]
Takes the outputs from the previous steps ([a] and [b] and uses the hstack (horizontal stack) filter on them to create the side by side output. This output is then named [out])
+
-map [out]
Maps the output of the filter chain
+
-f nut
Sets the format for the output video stream to Nut
+
-c:v rawvideo
Sets the video codec of the output video stream to raw video
+
-
Tells FFmpeg that the output will be piped to a new command (as opposed to a file)
+
|
Tells the system you will be piping the output of the previous command into a new command
+
ffplay -
Starts FFplay and tells it to use the pipe from the previous command as its input
+

/repos/amiaopensource/ffmprovisr/pulls/8.diff_hunk:
@@ -1075,6 +1075,48 @@ + + +
+
+
+
+

Set stream properties

+

Find undetermined or unknown stream properties

+

These examples use QuickTime inputs and outputs. The strategy will vary or may not be possible in other file formats. In the case of these examples it is the intention to make a lossless copy while clarifying an unknown characteristic of the stream.

+

ffprobe input_file -show_streams

+
+
ffprobe
starts the command
+
input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-show_streams
Shows metadata of stream properties
+
+

Values that are set to 'unknown' and 'undetermined' may be unspecified within the stream. An unknown aspect ratio would be expressed as '0:1'. Streams with many unknown properties may have interoperability issues or not play as intended. In many cases, an unknown or undetermined value may be accurate because the information about the source is unclear, but often the value is intended to be known. In many cases the stream will played with an assumed value if undetermined (for instance a display_aspect_ratio of '0:1' may be played as 'WIDTH:HEIGHT'), but this may or may not be what is intended. Use carefully.

+

+

Set aspect ratio

+

If the display_aspect_ratio is set to '0:1' it may be clarified with the -aspect option and stream copy.

+

ffmpeg -i input_file -c copy -map 0 -aspect DAR_NUM:DAR_DEN output_file

+
+
ffmpeg
starts the command
+
-i input_file
path, name and extension of the input file
+
-c copy
Usings stream copy for all streams
+
-map 0
Tells ffmpeg to map all streams of the input to the output.
+
-aspect DAR_NUM:DAR_DEN
Replace DAR_NUM with the display aspect ratio numerator and DAR_DEN with the display aspect ratio denominator, such as -aspect 4:3 or -aspect 16:9.
+
output_file
path, name and extension of the output file
+
+

Adding other stream properties.

+

Other properties may be clarified in a similar way. Replace -aspect and its value with other properties such as shown in the options below. Note that setting color values in QuickTime requires that -movflags write_colr is set.

+
+
-color_primary VALUE -movflags write_colr
Set a new color_primary value. The vocabulary for values is at ffmpeg.
+
-color_trc VALUE -movflags write_colr
Set a new color_transfer value. The vocabulary for values is at ffmpeg.
+
-field_order VALUE
Set interlacement values. The vocabulary for values is at ffmpeg.
